PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
1.  Although the design and modality of the project is proven effective from the experience 
of  earlier  phases,  a  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (PPTA)  is  needed  to  make 
necessary adjustments for more efficient execution of the project and improvements to enhance 
effectiveness and impacts of the project. The PPTA will carry out due diligence on technical, 
economic, financial, governance, poverty and social, and safeguards for the ensuing loan. 
Capacity building of target pourashavas is an integral part of project preparation, without which 
the implementation of the project may face significant start-up delays.  
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The key outputs are an agreed project design and feasibility study for the ensuing 
project that satisfies the requirements of ADB and the government. Capacity building support 
will help target pourashavas meet the performance criteria in governance improvement.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
4.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,450,000 equivalent. It is proposed that $1,000,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV), and the 
remaining $450,000 will be financed on a grant basis from the Multi-Donor Trust Fund under the 
Water  Financing  Partnership  Facility,  administered  by  ADB.1 The  government  will  provide 
counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff  including  their  per  diem  and  field 
transportation, office accommodation, office equipment, and logistical assistance for workshops, 
seminars, and training programs, and other in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimate is 
presented in Table A4.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
5.  The TA will require about 169 person-months of consulting services (25 international and 
144 national). A team of consultants will be recruited through a firm under one package using 
the quality- and cost-based method of selection with a quality-cost ratio of 90:10 in accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). This 
ratio is justified due to the complex nature of the assignment involving wide range of expertise 
and a large number of municipalities. Full technical proposal will be used for the selection of a 
firm. In addition, a small number of individual consultants may be engaged to enhance project 
readiness  and  expedite  project  implementation,  on  an  as-needed  basis.  The  summary  of 
consulting services requirement is presented in Table A4.3.

6.  During the first 6 months of the TA, the design of the project will be formulated and 
mutually agreed upon between the government and ADB. Tasks during this period will include 
(i) analysis of appropriate project modality based on a review of lessons from the previous 
phases of Urban Governance and Infrastructure Improvement (Sector) Project (UGIIP) and 
similar projects and an assessment of technical, procurement, and management capacity of the 
executing agencies, target pourashavas, and other key agencies involved in the project, with 
due consideration to the context of Bangladesh; (ii) drafting a sector development plan, a road 
map, or an urban sector program in accordance with ADB requirements of the selected project 
modality; (iii) recommending advancement of the policy and governance reform in the urban 
sector; (iv) financial assessment of sample pourashavas, including their financial projections, 
and proposals for sustainable operation and maintenance of project facilities;  (v) preparing 
profiles  of  sample  pourashavas  and  feasibility  studies  of  sample  subprojects  prioritized  in 
sample  pourashavas,  including  financial  and  economic  analyses  in  accordance  with  ADB 
requirements;  (vi)  review  and  improvement  of  the  performance  criteria  of  governance 
improvement  for  pourashavas;  (vii)  recommending  performance-based  fund  allocation 
mechanism according to a simple formula; (viii) social, poverty, and gender analysis, including 
preparation of a gender action plan; (ix) preparation of required safeguard documents;  (x) 
preparation of communication and participation plan during PPTA and implementation of the 
ensuing loan; (xi) preparation of a procurement plan for goods, works, and services, with 
suggested level of prior or, if applicable, post review based on the capacity assessment of the 
executing and implementing agencies; (xii) assessment of governance risks in the areas of 
financial  management,  procurement,  and  corruption,  and  development  of  risk  mitigation 
measures based on the assessment; (xiii) proposal of implementation schedule, detailed cost 
estimates and financing plan, as well as required consultants’ inputs and outline scope of work 
under  the  ensuing  project;  and  (xiv)  recommending  the  scope  of  work  of  the  capacity 
development TA associated with the loan. 
 
7.  Consultants will also provide support to enhance project readiness and expedite project 
start-up.  They  will  provide  intensive  capacity  building  support  to  priority  pourashavas  in

consideration  of  the  performance  criteria,  and  assist  the  Local  Government  Division  in 
undertaking  the  first  performance  assessment  of  target  pourashavas.  Profiles  of  priority 
pourashavas and feasibility studies of subprojects for priority pourashavas including economic 
and financial analysis and safeguards due diligence will be prepared to expedite the first-year 
implementation. The consultants will also assist the executing agencies in undertaking advance 
contracting, including for recruitment of loan consultants, and in preparing and seeking approval 
of Development Project Proforma. A procurement expert or other experts may be separately 
engaged on an as-needed basis to cater to specific needs of project processing and advance 
actions to enhance project readiness and expedite project implementation.   
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
8.  The TA will be implemented over 21 months, from June 2013 to March 2015. The 
executing  agencies  are  the  Local  Government  Engineering  Department  (LGED)  and 
Department of Public Health Engineering (DPHE), both under the Ministry of Local Government, 
Rural Development and Cooperatives (MLGRDC). An existing project management office in the 
LGED under the ongoing loan will take charge of supervising the TA work. The DPHE will 
appoint counterpart staff from the Feasibility Studies and Design Circle. A steering committee, 
chaired by the secretary of Local Government Division under the MLGRDC, will be established 
to provide overall policy guidance for the PPTA. Its membership will include LGED, DPHE, 
Economic  Relations  Division  and  Finance  Division  of  the  Ministry  of  Finance,  Planning 
Commission, and Municipal Association of Bangladesh. The TA coordinator from LGED will 
work as member and the convener of the steering committee. The government will provide: (i) 
any relevant documents, data, statistics, information, or maps that the government has at its 
disposal; (ii) adequate number of qualified counterpart staff, including their field per diem and 
field transportation; (iii) office accommodation and office equipment, including desks, chairs, and 
local communication; (iv) logistical assistance for the workshops and seminars, including venue 
provision  and  sending  invitations  to  participants;  and  (v)  other  in-kind  contributions.  The 
equipment procured under the TA will be turned over to LGED or DPHE at the end of the TA. All 
disbursements under the TA shall be made in accordance with the TA Disbursement Handbook 
(May 2010, as amended from time to time). The proposed TA processing and implementation 
schedule is listed in Table A4.4.
